text:
This is possibly more of a maths question, than a Python one and hopefully quite a simple one, but my brain appears to be malfunctioning.

All I am trying to do, is create a function that returns the win probability for a and b (be they runners or teams) for a series n length (for now not allowing draws) on the assumption the series ends after one a or b reaches the target number of games (e.g. 3 out of 5, 4 out of 7 etc) and therefore  when calculating for a, a always has to win the final game (and vice versa).

This is what I've come up with, however what's bugging me is that the summed probabilities keeps increasing the higher number of games in the series, so I'm trying to get my head round whether I've made a coding mistake or if there is a mathematical reason for this that I've missed?

```from math import ceil, pow, comb

def calc_win_probability(n, p_a, p_b=False):

    if p_b is False:
        p_b = 1-p_a

    g = ceil(n/2)
    prob_list = []
    for i in range(g,n+1):
        a = (comb(i,g-1) * pow(p_a,g-1) * pow(p_b,(i - (g-1)))) * p_a
        b = (comb(i,g-1) * pow(p_b,g-1) * pow(p_a,(i - (g-1)))) * p_b
        prob_list.append({'games': i, 'prob_a_win': a, 'prob_b_win': b, 'combined_prob': a+b})

    return {'overall_prob': sum([p['combined_prob'] for p in prob_list]) ,'prob_list': prob_list}

t = calc_win_probability(7,2/3,1/3)

for x in t['prob_list']:
    print(x,'\n','----------------------------------------------------------')
print({'total_prob': t['overall_prob']})```

text: marketCatalogues use 2018-10-26T18:45:00.000Z for datetime representation. I prefer to handle epoch timestamps, so i wanted to convert it. Does betfair always use Z (0 timezone) or does bf use diffrent timezones aswell?

text:
<https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/Additional+Information#AdditionalInformation-TimeZones&TimeFormat>

> All times are returned in GMT and are in ISO 8601 (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601>) format. They can be converted to your local timezone using the timezone field returned by the <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/docs/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/getAccountDetails|getAccountDetails> operation or into the local market timezone using the timezone returned for the event by <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/docs/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/listMarketCatalogue|listMarketCatalogue>

text:
Sorry, was sidetracked.

Yes, thats why I was ignoring cricket for now, I want to determine the probability of A to win, bearing in mind that:

The series ends once A reaches x out of n (e.g. 4/7)
There can be no draws
It is know prior to the start the probability each team has of winning an individual game

So what I'm struggling to get my head round is why is it not important to discount the unplayed games and factor in that A has to win the final game (or B when in reverse)?

So what I'm struggling to get my head round is why is it not important to discount the unplayed games and factor in that A has to win the final game (or B when in reverse)?

text: I agree with you here but if using binomial then we are assuming probabilities of each time winning are identical for each game. I can't help but feel that Binomial distribution is not quite right for this problem though. I mean take a MLB were the choice of starting pitcher has a massive effect on price. Is it not more accurate to just enumerate all possible outcomes using the respective probabilities for each distinct pair of probabilities. I feel that this question should have a simpler answer than what I am trying to make of it though.

text: once you see that the probability is independent of if all games are played or not, you will also see that you can disregard who wins last game. Just calculate the probability for a winning more than b over n matches. This will also be the probability for a winning over b if the series ends once a winner is decided
